results.title: Australia's Great Barrier Reef
results.creator_credit: David Hannan Productions, Television New Zealand Natural History Unit, David Hannan, David Reed, Janine Hedley and Russell Kelley
results.brief_description: Australia’s Great Barrier Reef is a visually vibrant documentary about the strange summer mating rituals that have resulted in the formation of one of the most stunning natural wonders of the world. A spectacular and sometimes surreal celebration of coral and reef society in general, focusing on the tactics used to perpetuate the species. Originally screened as “Sex of the Reef”. Winner of Golden Tripod Award for Wildlife and Nature at 25th Australian International Cinematographers Society Awards, and Gold Award Nature and Wildlife at the US International Film and Video Festival 1993.

results.title: Australia's first foreign war: the Waikato
results.creator_credit: Southern Latitude Films, Edwin Morrisby and John Laynton
results.brief_description: This documentary suggests that the Maori Wars of 1863-64, rather than the Sudan War of 1899-1901, were Australia’s first experience of war, by noting New Zealand’s governor, Sir George Grey’s activities in advertising for, and recruiting volunteers from the Australian colonies. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Australia's coral wonderland (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Kelly Monkman and Noel Monkman
results.brief_description: A picture of the life along the Great Barrier Reef; an aboriginal corroboree; flora and fauna on a trip down the Russell River; micro-photographs of animal life; underwater cinematography of an octopus, sea worms, a feathered star fish, a king schnapper, hermit crabs, sea anemones and other forms of life; scenes of turtles building nests and laying eggs; hatching of young turtles. Commentary by Wilfrid Thomas; sound by Mervyn Murphy and photography by Noel Monkman FRMS.

results.title: Australia's birds: Wetlands
results.creator_credit: GEO Wildlife Documentaries, Grant Young and Terence Lindsey
results.brief_description: Once wetlands covered a third of Australia, but that was a million years ago, and now the continent is very much drier. Australia’s remaining extensive wetlands are more or less restricted to the southeast, southwest, and the tropical north. Nevertheless, Australia has an extremely rich and varied aquatic avifauna, and its lakes, swamps and rivers are thronged with many species of birds. This video explores the fascinating relationship between 28 Australian aquatic birds and the wetlands, temporary or permanent, in which they spend their lives. Birds discussed are: Black Swan; Pied Stilt; Red-necked Avocet; Whiskered Tern; Grey Teal; Pink-eared Duck; Australasian Shoveler; Freckled Duck; Clamorous Reed-Warbler; Little Grassbird; Baillons Crake; Australian Crake; Spotless Crake; Buff-banded Rail; Eurasian Coot; Dusky Moorhen; Blue-billed Duck; Hardhead; Musk Duck; Australasian Grebe; Hoary-headed Grebe; Red-kneed Dotterel; Black-fronted Plover; Royal Spoonbill; Yellow-billed Spoonbill; White-faced Heron; Pacific Heron; Straw-necked Ibis.

results.title: Australia's birds : Woodlands
results.creator_credit: GEO Wildlife Documentaries, Grant Young and Terence Lindsey
results.brief_description: Most Australian woodlands are dominated by trees of a particular group - the eucalypts. Familiar to all Australians these distinctive trees have a number of special characteristics that set them apart, and these unique characteristics provide a wealth of challenges and opportunities for the birds that inhabits Australian woodlands, resulting in one of the richest and most diverse bird communities on the continent. This video focuses on the life histories and special feeding behaviours of 23 species of Australian woodland birds. Birds discussed are: Yellow Robin; Laughing Kookaburra; Grey Burtcherbird; Rufous Songlark; Pallid Cuckoo; Rufous Whistler; Rainbow Bee-eater; Sacred Kingfisher; White-winged Chough; Restless Flycatcher; Speckled Warbler; Peaceful Dove; Double-barred Finch; Varied Sittella; White-throated Treecreeper; Shriketit; Fuscous Honeyeater; Spotted Pardalote; Noisy Friarbird; Regent Honeyeater; Scarlet Honeyeater; Painted Honeyeater; Mistletoe Bird.

results.title: Australia's birds : Oceans
results.creator_credit: GEO Wildlife Documentaries and Grant Young
results.brief_description: Oceans make up about four-fifths of the Earths surface, and there are many kinds of birds that spend their lives roaming these vast expanses between continents, seldom finding themselves even within sight of land. Many come ashore only to nest. In size these ocean wanderers range from the albatrosses - some with wingspans nearing three metres, among the largest birds that fly - to the tiny storm-petrel, little bigger than a starling. This video tells the story of a cross-section of some of the more common and representative of these fascinating ocean wanderers. Birds discussed are: Wandering Albatross; Providence Petrel; Black-winged Petrel; Flesh-footed Shearwater; Wedge-tailed Shearwater; Australasian Gannet; Masked Booby; Sooty Tern; Grey Noddy; Brown Noddy; White Tern; Red-tailed Tropicbird.

results.title: Australia's Best: Music & Images of Australians in the 80's
results.creator_credit: New South Wales Film Corporation, South Pacific Films and Pom Oliver
results.brief_description: A music video documentary showcasing the best of Australia’s popular music in the eighties. Features the music of Split Enz, Australian Crawl, INXS, No Fixed Address, Cold Chisel and Icehouse. Includes interviews with celebrities such as Michael Hutchence, Neil and Tim Finn, James Reyne and Grace Knight.

results.title: Australia's art of the Dreamtime: Quinkin country (A)
results.creator_credit: WIPB-TV, Ball State University and Jim Needham
results.brief_description: An informative and educational documentary on the history of Australian Aborigines and their rock art in the Cape York Peninsula region of Queensland. The program explores not only the historical background of the rock paintings but theorises on the first arrival of Aborigines to this land and the formation of the landscape itself through archeological, geological and palaentological evidence. During the 1950s Australian artist and author Percy Trezise went on a quest to locate the rock art around Laura in the Cape York region and through contact with Aboriginal elders and befriending Aboriginal writer, Dick Roughsey, he was eventually accepted as a “tribal brother”. In this program, Percy, using images from his own paintings, interprets Aboriginal Dreamtime stories, mythology and initiation ceremonies as represented by the rock paintings. He speaks of his own experiences and respect for the Aboriginal people, their culture and their heritage. Voice over narration by Chris Schenkel. Note: Visual quality average - filmed on video camera.

results.title: Australia's anti-war movement: 1965-1972
results.brief_description: The initially small minority protesting against Australian involvement in the Vietnam War flourished into a massive mobilisation against the war that not only ended Australian participation in the war, but also radicalised and irreversibly changed Australian society. In this video three participants in the anti-war movement discuss their involvement. Irene Miller was an original member of the Save Our Sons Movement, one of the earliest of the anti-war organisations. Michael Hamel-Green was a draft resister and he gives a fascinating account of the “underground” movement which worked to protect draft resisters from prison by installing them in “safe houses”. Jean McLean discusses the history of the anti-war movement and the lead up to the first anti-war Moratorium in 1970, the largest protest in Australia’s history.

results.title: Australia's 1st International Girl Guides Camp
results.brief_description: The activities and amusements which made up the life of those attending the first International Girl Guides Camp to be held in Australia are shown. Guides came from many countries including Great Britain, USA and the Far East. The arrival at the camp site and settling in are followed by scenes depicting cooking, washing, singing and the other aspects of camp life. Amusements include a visit to Healesville Wild Life Sanctuary, an exhibition of boomerang throwing and national dances. The film concludes with a portrait of Lady Baden-Powell.
